learn_section_decoded:
## Central Limit Theorem (CLT)

The Central Limit Theorem states that if we take many independent samples of size $n$ from any distribution with finite mean $\mu$ and variance $\sigma^2$, the distribution of the standardized sample mean approaches a standard normal distribution as $n$ becomes large.

### Sample Mean
Given a sample $X_1, X_2, \dots, X_n$ from a distribution with mean $\mu$ and variance $\sigma^2$:
$$
\bar{X} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i
$$

### Standardized Form
The standardized mean is:
$$
Z = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}
$$

### CLT Result
As $n \to \infty$:
$$
Z \sim N(0, 1)
$$

This result holds regardless of the original distribution, as long as variance is finite.
